rounds.comments: (Alex: Each response will have a silent "L".)

clues.text: You're pulling my leg! This fleshy part in the back of my leg
This light yellowish-pink color sure sounds fishy
Any oily substance of medicinal value derived from certain plants; you're the...!
To fill the seams between planks to make watertight
Limestone writing implement
This legendary golfer looked back on "A Life Well Played"
"In Praise of Difficult Women" praises this "Parks & Rec" star & 28 other "Heroines Who Dared to Break the Rules"
His story was that of "The Life and Legacy of Chile's Controversial Dictator"
"Swan: The Life and Dance of" this Russian is one bio of her; so is "Twentieth Century Ballerina"
One book examines the "Literary Life" of this 18th century English poet known for his savage wit & satire
"The very existence of" this James Bond chief, "let alone his identity, was never admitted"
Niacin is part of this vitamin group
Rolling Stone's list of the 500 greatest albums of all time includes 2 by this L.A. punk quartet
Einstein used it to denote the speed of light
In chess notation, this, not K, denotes a knight
For the bicentennial, PEZ put its first real people on dispensers, one being this Kentucky frontiersman
Named for his literary relative, Edgar Allan Poe was named to the 1st of these elite college athletic teams in 1889
Known as "The Liberty Bell of the West", the Kaskaskia bell is found on an island in this state
Walter Chrysler & Elizabeth Arden are among those taking a "snooze" at this New York cemetery near Tarrytown
A witness in a 1950s Senate crime probe invoked this, refusing to answer "on the grounds it might intend to criminate him"
60 conspirators helped knock off Julius Caesar in 44 B.C., but as far as we know, only he got the "et tu" thrown at him
The going rate for selling out America in 1780? For him, 6,315 pounds, but it's not like his name was totally destroyed...oh wait
FBI Soviet analyst Robert Hanssen began spying for this overseas intelligence agency in 1985
Last name of the couple who in 1953 were the first U.S. civilians to be executed for espionage
In 480 B.C. the traitorous Ephialtes helped the Persians outflank the Greeks at this mountain pass
An Egyptian sun god, or a cheerleader's exclamation
Jupiter's sister-wife, or an Alaskan panhandle city
Sneaky Norse bad guy, or a hyphenated word for "understated"
A Roman food goddess, or another word for "TV show"
A deadly Hindu goddess, or a deadly Colombian drug cartel
The dream of Baltimore teen Tracy Turnblad is to dance on the Corny Collins show in this '60s-set film
Somebody put Baby in a clue when Jennifer Grey starred in this 1987 film set in the Catskills
Sebastian & Mia sing & dance above the lights of the city in this 2016 film
Gene Kelly says, "From where I stand, the sun is shining all over the place" before he dances & croons this tune
She's a welder! She's a dancer! She's drenched! The "she" is Jennifer Beals; this is the 1983 film
The shamrock is a symbol of this March celebration
It begins, "Our Father which art in heaven, hallowed be thy name"
"If anything can go wrong, it will", at least according to this proposition
In a Civil War song, this "lies a-mouldering in the grave"
In January 1848 carpenter James Marshall reported the discovery of gold at this spot

Latin:
"To a sickening degree"

French:
"Pen name"

German:
"Lightning war"

Italian:
"In the style of a chapel"

Russian:
"Grandmother"
The assassination that sparked World War I took place in this city
At Xmas in this year soldiers played soccer with foes; the next year orders were given to kill anyone trying the same
This fence material became a deadly instrument; the National WWI Musem sells a replica soldier hanging on it
German forces gave units from this U.K. land the nickname "the ladies from hell" for their fighting spirit & uniforms
Not to be confused with the Ardennes, this French forest was the site of the biggest WWI battle fought by the AEF
In Connecticut a white male needed land worth 2 pounds a year in rent or livestock worth 40 pounds to be able to do this
Now the name of a Harvard theatrical club, it was a porridge of milk & flour or cornmeal
In mid-Atlantic states, leaves of this New World crop were often used as currency
This 3-letter cap sounds like it was for an unruly crowd, but it was a bonnet for women to wear indoors
Patrick Henry slept at the governor's palace in what's now this Virginia tourist mecca
The world's more than 400 nuclear power plants use this process of splitting an atom in 2 to create energy
The diameter of the nucleus is a few femto-these or quadrillionths of that unit
A gamma particle is a high-energy one of these light particles emitted during radioactive disintegration
This word once used by alchemists today means the changing of one element into another by a nuclear reaction
The sun is a fusion reactor; creating one on Earth would require creating this very hot, ionized state of matter

rounds.text: Its first line says, "The good people of Paris were awakened by a grand peal from all the bells in the three districts of the city"
